message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Manufacturing Consent
Paper Abstract: Chapter 6 empirically tests whether and how participatory technologies influence political attitudes. Using two original survey experiments and qualitative data from interviews and focus groups, this chapter examines the impact of awareness of the Direct Line on approval of President Putin and perceptions of voice. The results indicate that participatory technologies have a positive impact on attitudes toward authorities. It also argues that, while government responsiveness to citizen demands does improve attitudes toward autocrats, the mere presence of participation opportunities bolsters support regardless of authorities' response to these demands.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "participatory technology"

Links: [{"title":"Participatory technology development - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Participatory_technology_development"},{"title":"Participatory design - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Participatory_design"},{"title":"Participatory culture - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Participatory_culture"},{"title":"Participatory planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Participatory_planning"},{"title":"Participatory development - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Participatory_development"},{"title":"Civic technology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Civic_technology"},{"title":"Participatory media - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Participatory_media"},{"title":"Participatory sensing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Participatory_sensing"},{"title":"Patient participation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patient_participation"},{"title":"Participatory information service - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Participatory_information_service"}]

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about participatory technology:

## Key Concepts

Participatory technology development (PTD) is an approach to learning and innovation that is used in international development as part of projects and programmes relating to sustainable agriculture.(no content)The approach involves collaboration between researchers and farmers in the analysis of agricultural problems and testing of alternative farming practices.

More broadly, participatory approaches span multiple domains:

- **Participatory Design**: Participatory design is an approach to design that attempts to involve a variety of stakeholders (e.g. employees, partners, customers, citizens, end users) in the design process to help ensure the result meets their needs and is usable.

- **Participatory Media**: Participatory media is communication media where the audience can play an active role in the process of collecting, reporting, analyzing and disseminating content.

- **Participatory Sensing**: Participatory sensing is the concept of communities (or other groups of people) contributing sensory information to form a body of knowledge.

## Applications

Participatory approaches are used in a variety of fields, including software design, urban design, architecture, landscape architecture, product design, sustainability, graphic design, industrial design, planning, and health services development.

These approaches emphasize collaboration, user involvement, and ensuring that technology solutions are appropriate for those who use them.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "survey experiment"

Links: [{"title":"Field experiment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Field_experiment"},{"title":"Conjoint analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conjoint_analysis"},{"title":"Survey (human research) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Survey_(human_research)"},{"title":"Observational study - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observational_study"},{"title":"Sample size determination - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sample_size_determination"},{"title":"Dark Energy Spectroscopic Instrument - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dark_Energy_Spectroscopic_Instrument"},{"title":"Randomized experiment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Randomized_experiment"},{"title":"Survey methodology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Survey_methodology"},{"title":"Randomized response - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Randomized_response"},{"title":"Survey response effects - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Survey_response_effects"}]

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about survey experiments:

## Overview

Survey experiments are a type of research design that combines elements of surveys and experimental methodology. While the results don't provide a single comprehensive definition, they reveal several key approaches:

## Conjoint Experiments

One important form of survey experiment is the conjoint experiment, where a controlled set of potential products or services, broken down by attribute, is shown to survey respondents, and by analyzing how respondents choose among the products, the respondents' valuation of the attributes making up the products or services can be determined. Conjoint analysis is a survey-based statistical technique used in market research that helps determine how people value different attributes that make up an individual product or service.

## Validation Through Experiments

Researchers have used field experiments by posting different types of employment ads to test people's preferences for stable versus exciting jobs as a way to check the validity of people's responses to survey measures.

## Response Effects

Another important aspect of survey experiments involves studying survey response effects, which are variations in survey responses that result from seemingly inconsequential aspects of survey design and administration.

Survey experiments are valuable research tools that allow researchers to combine the flexibility of surveys with experimental controls to test theories and understand how people value attributes and make decisions.

Survey experiments are a type of research design that combines elements of surveys and experimental methodology. While the results don't provide a single comprehensive definition, they reveal several key approaches:

## Conjoint Experiments

One important form of survey experiment is the conjoint experiment, where a controlled set of potential products or services, broken down by attribute, is shown to survey respondents, and by analyzing how respondents choose among the products, the respondents' valuation of the attributes making up the products or services can be determined. Conjoint analysis is a survey-based statistical technique used in market research that helps determine how people value different attributes that make up an individual product or service.

## Validation Through Experiments

Researchers have used field experiments by posting different types of employment ads to test people's preferences for stable versus exciting jobs as a way to check the validity of people's responses to survey measures.

## Response Effects

Another important aspect of survey experiments involves studying survey response effects, which are variations in survey responses that result from seemingly inconsequential aspects of survey design and administration.

Survey experiments are valuable research tools that allow researchers to combine the flexibility of surveys with experimental controls to test theories and understand how people value attributes and make decisions.

I've performed a web search on "political attitude" and retrieved comprehensive information about the topic. Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Scope

Political attitude is "the set of attitudes, beliefs, and sentiments, which give order and meaning to a political process and which provide the underlying assumptions and rules that govern behavior in the political system."

## Research on Political Attitudes

Scholars have studied political attitudes across various dimensions. In 1950, Leonard W. Ferguson analyzed political values using ten scales measuring attitudes toward birth control, capital punishment, censorship, communism, evolution, law, patriotism, theism, treatment of criminals and war, identifying three factors which he named religionism, humanitarianism and nationalism.(no content)Later, Hans Eysenck drew out two factors through factor analysis, which he named "Radicalism" (R-factor) and "Tender-Mindedness" (T-factor).

## Formation of Political Attitudes

Political socialization is the process by which individuals internalize and develop their political values, ideas, attitudes, and perceptions via the agents of socialization.(no content)The most significant agents include families, media, education, and peers.(no content)Literature has heavily emphasized that the agent of the family is the most influential, with literature suggesting that family and the transmission of attitudes from parent to child are the most prominent agents of socialization.

The search results provide a detailed overview of how political attitudes are conceptualized, measured, and developed in individuals and societies.

If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

I've completed a web search for "citizen engagement government response." Here are the key findings:

## Overview of Citizen Engagement

Civic engagement can foster community participation and government involvement. The relationship between citizens and government has multiple dimensions and benefits.

## Benefits of Government Response to Citizen Engagement

When governments respond effectively to citizen engagement, several positive outcomes occur:

- Engendering trust between citizens and government, attaining successful outcomes on complex issues, developing more creative ideas and better solutions, and implementing ideas, programs, and policies faster and more easily
- Achieving greater buy-in to decisions with fewer backlashes such as lawsuits, special elections, or a council recall

## Forms of Government Response

Governments use various mechanisms to respond to citizen engagement:

- Citizen sourcing is a new approach to coproduction of public services enabled by Web 2.0 technologies, including the use of ideation tools to collect ideas, problem-solving tools to identify solutions, citizen reporting platforms, and monitoring social media for situational awareness
- Online engagement allows citizens to voice themselves from their homes through online voting and public discussion forums where citizens can voice opinions, offer solutions, and find others with common interests

## Key Requirements for Success

For civic engagement to succeed, a layer of transparency and trust between the government and its citizens is needed. Additionally, people who serve state governments learn what the community needs through listening to citizens and thus make nuanced decisions.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "experimental design research methodology"

Links: [{"title":"Design of experiments - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Design_of_experiments"},{"title":"Research design - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Research_design"},{"title":"The Design of Experiments - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Design_of_Experiments"},{"title":"Design-based research - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Design-based_research"},{"title":"Experimental political science - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Experimental_political_science"},{"title":"Category:Design of experiments - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Design_of_experiments"},{"title":"Quasi-experiment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quasi-experiment"},{"title":"Glossary of experimental design - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glossary_of_experimental_design"},{"title":"Optimal experimental design - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimal_experimental_design"},{"title":"Experiment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Experiment"}]

I found comprehensive information about experimental design research methodology. Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Overview

An experimental design is the laying out of a detailed experimental plan in advance of doing the experiment. More broadly, an experiment is a procedure carried out to support or refute a hypothesis, or determine the efficacy or likelihood of something previously untried, and experiments provide insight into cause-and-effect by demonstrating what outcome occurs when a particular factor is manipulated.

## Key Principles

Fisher established randomization as the "physical basis of the validity of the test" as his first principle of experimental design, and went on to integrate randomization with two further principles, replication and blocking, to form a general framework for designing experiments.

## Core Elements of Experimental Design

In an experimental design, the researcher actively tries to change the situation, circumstances, or experience of participants (manipulation), which may lead to a change in behavior or outcomes for the participants of the study. The researcher randomly assigns participants to different conditions, measures the variables of interest, and tries to control for confounding variables.(no content)In a true experiment, researchers can have an experimental group, which is where their intervention testing the hypothesis is implemented, and a control group, which has all the same element as the experimental group, without the interventional element. Thus, when everything else except for one intervention is held constant, researchers can certify with some certainty that this one element is what caused the observed change.

## Applications

Correctly designed experiments advance knowledge in the natural and social sciences and engineering, with design of experiments methodology recognised as a key tool in the successful implementation of a Quality by Design (QbD) framework.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.
